questions.question: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of continuous leakage of urine from her vagina for the past 3 months since her last delivery. She is not able to hold urine. She reports having experienced prolonged & obstructed labor during her last delivery. On examination, her thighs and vulva were excoriated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Vesicovaginal fistula Explanation: This patient's history of prolonged and obstructed labor followed by continuous leakage of urine from the vagina without micturition strongly suggests a Vesicovaginal fistula. It's also the most common type of urinary fistula. Obstructed Labor is the most common cause for the development of VVF in Developing countries. (Developed countries - Hysterectomy). Vesicovaginal fistula: It is an abnormal communication between the bladder and vagina, typically caused by prolonged obstructed labor where pressure necrosis occurs between the bladder and vagina due to prolonged compression of the fetal presenting part against the pelvic bones. This leads to tissue breakdown and formation of a fistula, resulting in continuous leakage of urine through the vagina. Bladder Fistula Ureteric Fistula Aetiology Mostly obstetric causes Prolonged labour vaginal caesarean section. sling operations hysterectomy Following surgical procedures i.e. LSCS Clinical Continuous dribbling of urine - no micturition Continuous dribbling of urine but can also, micturate Methylene swab test Swab stains with methylene blue Swab stains with urine but not with methylene blue Types of Urinary Fistulae: Bladder Ureter Urethra Vesicovaginal fistula Vesicocervical fistula Vesicouterine fistula Ureterovaginal fistula Ureteroabdominal fistula Urethrovaginal fistula Sites of Ureteric Injury: 2cm Lateral to Internal os (most common site) Infundibulopelvic ligament Ureteric tunnel (during Wertheim hysterectomy) Near entry of the ureter into the bladder during bladder dissection Near the pelvic brim (during ligation of the internal iliac artery) Near the uterosacral ligament (during laparoscopic procedures, vault closure, and in endometriosis) Vesicouterine fistula (Option B) involves communication between the bladder and uterus. It is less common and typically presents with continuous urinary incontinence and amenorrhea. Ureterovaginal fistula (Option C) involves an abnormal communication between the ureter and vagina, usually due

questions.question: A 28-year-old primigravida woman has been in labor for the past 20 hours with little progress despite strong contractions. Despite attempts at assisted vaginal delivery, the labor is not progressing. Because of obstructed labor, an emergency cesarean section is performed. Postoperatively, the patient complains of continuous leakage of fluid from her vagina and inability to hold urine. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Vesicovaginal fistula Explanation: In the above clinical condition the patient presented with obstructed labor and was managed with emergency cesarean section, with postoperative patient complaints of leakage of urine through the vagina. This is a classical case of vesico-vaginal fistula. Vesico-vaginal fistula (VVF): Vesico-vaginal fistula (VVF) is an abnormal passage which develops between the bladder and the vagina, leading to continuous and involuntary discharge of urine through the vagina. This condition typically results from prolonged obstructed labor or pelvic surgery complications, where tissues between the bladder and the vagina are damaged, causing the formation of the fistula. Management: Conservative Surgical Genitourinary fistulas may spontaneously close during continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter. In 10 percent of cases, urinary fistulas close spontaneously after 2 to 8 weeks of transurethral catheterization, especially if the fistula is small. Transvaginal Repair: This approach involves accessing the fistula through the vaginal wall. It is suitable for smaller fistulas and those located in favorable positions that allow for direct access and closure. Transabdominal Repair: Larger or more complex fistulas may require an abdominal approach. This can be done via laparotomy (open surgery) or laparoscopy (minimally invasive surgery). Laparoscopy is preferred when feasible as it offers faster recovery and reduced postoperative complications. Stress Incontinence (Option A): This involves urine leakage during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, like coughing or sneezing. It does not cause continuous leakage. Uretero Vaginal Fistula (Option B): This condition involves a connection between a ureter and the vagina, leading to continuous leakage of urine from one kidney. It's less common than VVF and typically follows surgery involving the ureters. Urge Incontinence (Option D): This is characterized by a sudden, intense urge to urinate followed by involuntary urine loss. It does not cause continuous leakage and is related to overactive bladder rather than an anatomical fistula. Reference: Williams textbook 4th edition pg no 578

questions.question: A 45-year-old female patient presents with a complaint of continuous urinary leakage that has persisted for several weeks. Her medical history is significant for a recent hysterectomy performed six weeks ago. On physical examination, there is a constant trickle of clear fluid from the vagina. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cystoscopy with dye Explanation: The most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis of continuous urinary leakage following a recent hysterectomy, which suggests a vesicovaginal fistula (VVF), is: Cystoscopy with dye . Vesico-vaginal fistula (VVF): Vesico-vaginal fistula (VVF) is an abnormal passage which develops between the bladder and the vagina, leading to continuous and involuntary discharge of urine through the vagina Investigations of genitourinary fistulas: Cystoscopy with dye test It involves inserting a dye solution (methylene blue)for confirming the diagnosis. MRI or CT Scan These imaging modalities may be used to assess complex cases or to plan surgical repair, providing detailed anatomical information. Intravenous pyelogram (IVP) (IVP) is a diagnostic imaging test that is not typically used as a primary method to diagnose vesico-vaginal fistula (VVF). Reference: William textbook for gynecology pg 578

questions.question: A 29-year-old female with a history of 2 prior C-sections came to gynecology OPD with amenorrhoea and cyclic hematuria and her Urine Pregnancy Test was negative. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Youssef syndrome Explanation: The most probable diagnosis of the above clinical case with amenorrhoea and cyclic hematuria with 2 prior C-sections is Youssef syndrome Youssef syndrome Vesicouterine fistula is one of the rare varieties of urogenital fistula. Type I urogenital fistula or Youssef syndrome is characterized by menouria (vesical menstruation), amenorrhoea, and urinary continence and it mostly follows lower segment cesarean delivery. Surgery is the definitive treatment of choice. It consists of hysterectomy followed by the closure of bladder fistula opening Reference: William textbook for gynecology pg 578-579

questions.question: Which of the following is the trans-vaginal approach for the repair of vesico-vaginal fistula?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Latzko technique Explanation: The transvaginal approach for the surgical repair of the vesico-vaginal fistula is Latzko technique. Management of VVF: Conservative Surgical Genitourinary fistulas may spontaneously close during continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter. In 10 percent of cases, urinary fistulas close spontaneously after 2 to 8 weeks of transurethral catheterization, especially if the fistula is small. Transvaginal Repair/ Latzko method: This approach involves accessing the fistula through the vaginal wall. It is suitable for smaller fistulas and those located in favorable positions that allow for direct access and closure. Transabdominal Repair: Larger or more complex fistulas may require an abdominal approach. This can be done via laparotomy or laparoscopy Laparoscopy is preferred when feasible as it offers faster recovery and reduced postoperative complications. Lash and lash surgery (option A) This procedure is used for transvaginal approach of cervical cerclage Delorme's operation (option B) Used to treat rectal prolapse. Altemeier procedure (option D) Used for the treatment of rectal prolapse. Reference: Williams textbook page 578-579

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of urinary leakage. She reports that she leaks urine when she coughs, sneezes, or exercises. She also experiences occasional sudden urges to urinate that she cannot control, especially when she hears running water or after holding her urine for some time. Which types of urinary incontinence are likely present in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Mixed urinary incontinence Explanation: Mixed urinary incontinence refers to a combination of two types of urinary incontinence: stress urinary incontinence (SUI) and urge urinary incontinence (UUI). This condition is characterised by symptoms of both types occurring concurrently in an individual. Individuals with mixed urinary incontinence experience symptoms of both SUI and UUI. They may have leakage of urine during activities that increase abdominal pressure (SUI), as well as sudden urges to urinate that lead to involuntary leakage (UUI). Types of urinary incontinence: Type Description Stress urinary incontinence Involuntary loss of urine with effort or physical exertion or when sneezing or coughing. Urgency urinary incontinence Involuntary loss of urine associated with urgency or sudden, compelling desire to void that is difficult to defer. Mixed urinary incontinence Involuntary loss of urine associated with urgency and with physical exertion, sneezing or coughing. Overactive bladder Urinary urgency, typically accompanied by frequency and nocturia, with or without urge urinary incontinence, in the absence of urinary tract infection or other obvious pathology. Nocturnal enuresis Involuntary loss of urine that occurs during sleep. Functional urinary incontinence Involuntary loss of urine that is due to cognitive, functional, or mobility impairments in the presence of an intact lower urinary tract system. Reference: Williams Textbook of Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page 512

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman, 6 months postpartum after her second child, presents to her obstetrician with complaints of occasional urine leakage when she sneezes or laughs. She reports these symptoms started after childbirth and have been gradually worsening. Which of the following factors is not typically associated with the condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Maintenance of urethrovesical angle Explanation: The condition mentioned above based on history is stress urinary incontinence which involves descent of the bladder neck below levator ani muscles and loss of urethrovesical angle (70-80%) which causes funneling of the bladder neck and upper urethra. Causes of stress urinary incontinence: Atony of pelvic floor muscles Damage to pudendal nerve during vaginal delivery Other etiologies: Intrinsic sphincter defect (20-25%) Detrusor overactivity Risk factors: Age Obesity (BMI>20) Smoking Pregnancy Cognitive and functional impairment Chronically increased abdominal pressure (Chronic cough, constipation, occupational lifting) Urge urinary incontinence: Involuntary loss of urine is associated with a compelling desire to void but an inability to control the dribbling of urine. Risk factors: Neurological conditions Bladder inflammation and infection Chronic constipation can exacerbate symptoms by increasing intra-abdominal pressure. (Option A) COPD results in chronic cough which in turn increases abdominal pressure leading to worsening of incontinence symptoms (Option B) Multiparous women after repeated child births are prone to loss of tone of the pelvic floor muscles. (Option D)

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman who recently gave birth to her third child via vaginal delivery presents with complaints of occasional leakage of urine when she sneezes or laughs. She reports that these symptoms started about two months after childbirth and have been gradually worsening. On examination, there is no evidence of urinary tract infection. What type of urinary incontinence is most likely affecting this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Stress urinary incontinence Explanation: Given the patient's history of leakage during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure after childbirth, the most likely type of urinary incontinence affecting her is stress urinary incontinence. Type of Incontinence Clinical Features Stress Incontinence Leakage with physical activity (coughing, sneezing, exercise) Small amounts of urine lost Urge Incontinence Sudden, intense urge to urinate followed by leakage Frequent urination, including nocturia Overflow Incontinence Frequent or constant dribbling of urine Weak stream, hesitancy Feeling of bladder fullness, incomplete voiding Functional Incontinence Inability to reach the bathroom in time Normal urinary system function Reflex Incontinence Involuntary loss of urine without warning or urge Occurs at predictable intervals or situations Mixed urinary incontinence has features of both stress and urge incontinence (Option C) Occult stress incontinence refers to stress urinary incontinence that is not apparent during normal circumstances but becomes evident only when the bladder is repositioned, such as during pelvic organ prolapse reduction. (Option D) Reference: Williams Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page 512

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman who recently gave birth via vaginal delivery presents with complaints of urinary leakage when she coughs, sneezes, or exercises. She reports that these symptoms started shortly after childbirth and have been affecting her daily activities. Which investigation is not done for further evaluation of her condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Cystoscopy Explanation: The condition mentioned above based on history is urinary incontinence for which cystoscopy is not routinely indicated. It is typically reserved for investigating abnormalities within the bladder or urethra, such as bladder stones or tumors. Genuine stress incontinence of urine (SUI/GSI): Genuine stress incontinence (GSI) of urine occurs when the bladder pressure exceeds urethral pressure during physical stress in the absence of detrusor contraction. Investigations for Urinary Incontinence: Urine Culture (Option A) Essential to rule out urinary tract infections before invasive tests. Stress Test Objective method to demonstrate stress urinary incontinence (SUI). Q-Dip cotton Swab Test: (outdated) Evaluates bladder neck mobility. Positive test if swab angle increases significantly (>20°). Marshall's and Bonney's Test: (outdated) Checks for the absence of urine leakage post-bladder neck elevation. Indicates potential benefit from surgical repair if negative. Urethroscopy Visualizes urethra, trigone, and bladder neck. Urodynamic testing: (Option C) Group of tests to assess urine storage and voiding. Urodynamic studies help diagnose the type and severity of urinary incontinence. Cystometry Measures bladder and urethral pressures during artificial filling to differentiate types of incontinence. Urethrocystometry Assesses urethral pressure dynamics, crucial for diagnosing incontinence conditions. Uroflowmetry Measures urine flow rate and volume, providing non-invasive data on voiding function. Micturition Cystourethrography Evaluates the urethrovesical angle to diagnose stress incontinence. Uroprofilometry Measures dynamic urethral pressures, crucial for diagnosing urethral conditions. Ultrasonography (Option B) Measures bladder volume and residual urine; useful for identifying bladder wall abnormalities. Videocystourethrography Integrates pressure studies with video to assess lower urinary tract function. MRI Studies Assesses pelvic floor muscle defects; helpful for surgical planning to correct incontinence. Reference: Williams Gynecology, 4th Edition, Pages 524-527

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman with no medical comorbidities complaints of involuntary leakage of urine primarily when she coughs or sneezes. She has tried Kegel exercises, lifestyle modifications, such as avoiding caffeine, and pessary but these have not significantly improved her symptoms. What would be the most appropriate next step in the management of her condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Colposuspension surgery Explanation: In this scenario, all the conservative and less invasive measures have failed. Hence, the next best step in management is colposuspension surgery. Treatment of urinary incontinence: Type of urinary Incontinence Stress urinary Incontinence Urgency urinary Incontinence Overflow Incontinence Step 1 Lifestyle Weight loss in obese individuals Reduce fluid and caffeine intake Avoiding bladder irritants (e.g., caffeine, alcohol, carbonated drinks) Restrict intake of fluid to 1 liter/day If non-obstructive pathology Continuous catheter drainage Intermittent self-catheterization Step 2 Pelvic floor muscle training( Kegel exercises) Biofeedback therapy Scheduled Voiding Bladder retraining Scheduled voiding If obstructive pathology Alpha-blockers (tamsulosin for bladder outlet obstruction) Urethroplasty for urethral strictures Step 3 Medical Treatment Estrogen Sympathomimetic drugs ( α -adrenergic) Imipramine Medical Treatment Anticholinergics: Oxybutynin Tolterodine Fesoterodine fumarate Darifenacin Beta -3 adrenergic agonist (Mirabegron* ) Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., imipramine) Step 4 Devices Pessary Urethral Inserts Neuromodulation Sacral nerve stimulation Peripheral tibial nerve stimulation Intradetrusor botulinum toxin A injection Step 5 Surgical Treatment Colposuspension Midurethral tape Tension-free vaginal tape (TVT) Transobturator tape (TOT) Microslings Bladder neck suspension Bulking agents injection Others Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz (MMK) Paravaginal repair Surgical Treatment Cystoplasty (to increase bladder capacity) Urinary diversion procedures (eg. ileal conduit) Note: Mirabegron contraindicated in severe uncontrolled hypertension systolic blood pressure ≥ 180 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure ≤ 110 mm Hg, or both Mirabegron is better tolerated than antimuscarinics in older patients and can be considered as an alternative to antimuscarinics for elderly patients. Reference: DC Dutta gynecology, 8th edition, Pg 338-343, Williams 4th edition, pg 527-533, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26828974/

questions.question: A 55-year-old female presents with complaints of frequent urination, urgency, and urge incontinence, which have been worsening over the past seven months and significantly affecting her quality of life. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for the initial pharmacological management of overactive bladder in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Oxybutynin Explanation: Oxybutynin is a muscarinic receptor antagonist, used to treat overactive bladder or urgency urinary incontinence by relaxing the bladder muscle. Medical management of Urgency urinary incontinence or overactive bladder: Drug Mechanism of action Oxybutynin (Option A) Tolterodine Fesoterodine fumarate Trospium chloride Antimuscarinic Darifenacin Solifenacin M3-selective antimuscarinic Imipramine Tricyclic antidepressant, anticholinergic, α -adrenergic, antihistamine Mirabegron β 3 adrenergic agonist Medical management of stress urinary incontinence: Drug Mechanism of action Estrogen (useful in postmenopausal patient) (Option B) Increase urethral blood flow and α -adrenergic receptor sensitivity Imipramine Tricyclic antidepressant, anticholinergic, α -adrenergic, antihistamine Tamsulosin is used in non-neurogenic voiding dysfunction (Option C) Botulinum toxin A Injection into the bladder wall is approved for the treatment of idiopathic detrusor overactivity. It is not the initial treatment option. (Option D) Reference: Reference: DC Dutta gynecology, 8th edition, Pg 338-343, Williams 4th edition, pg 527-533, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26828974/ , https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2800025/

questions.question: A 50-year-old female presents with stress urinary incontinence. Conservative treatments have not alleviated her symptoms and the decision is made to proceed with a tension-free transvaginal tape (TVT) procedure. Which specific anatomical space is the tape positioned by the surgeon in this procedure?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Space of Retzius Explanation: Tension-free transvaginal tape (TVT) procedure is used to treat stress urinary incontinence (SUI) in women. Tape is passed vaginally under the midurethral and passed along the back of the pubic bone (Space of Retzius or the Retropubic Space) to the skin incision one on either sides. Surgical management of stress urinary incontinence (SUI): Principles of surgery: Restoration of anatomy so bladder neck and proximal urethra as made as intra-abdominal structures. Strengthening the support of bladder neck and proximal urethra. Procedure Key concepts Burch colposuspension (gold standard) The ipsilateral iliopectineal ligament is sutured to the endopelvic fascia and/or the lateral vaginal fornix. Tension-free vaginal tape (TVT) (option B) Tape is passed vaginally under the midurethral and along the back of the pubic bone (retropubic space) as depicted in the figure below. Transobturator tape (TOT) (option A) Sling material is passed bilaterally through the obturator foramen and underneath the mid urethra. Minimally invasive slings "Microslings" or "minislings" are TVT and TOT modifications. The mesh does not enter through the obturator foramen or the retropubic area. Pubovaginal sling procedures Functions via urethra compression at the urethrovesical junction. Surgery of choice for SUI: 1st- TOT 2nd- TVT 3rd- Burch colposuspension Surgical management of urgency urinary incontinence (UUI): Pelvic floor electrical stimulation Direct sacral neuromodulation (S3) Peripheral neuromodulation through peripheral tibial nerve stimulation (PTN) to sacral nerve plexus. Augmentation cystoplasty (to increase bladder capacity) Urinary diversion (ideal conduit). Option C: Presacral space is an anatomical area located between the rectum and the sacrum. It is useful in oncological, endometriosis surgeries involving low anterior resection of rectum. Option D: The pararectal space is an anatomical region delineated by the pelvic walls and the rectum. It is useful in oncological, pelvic abscess drainage and hysterectomy.
